description: 25x40mm caseless rounds.  The most common type of ammo used for high-gauge shotguns and light grenade launchers.  Being caseless, these cannot be disassembled or reloaded.

10mm ammunition with a brass jacketed bullet.  For as long as you can remember bullets like thse have been used for military, law enforcement, and civilian use.  Being caseless, these cannot be disassembled or reloaded.

10mm ammunition with hollow point bullet.  While they have inferior penetration to FMJ rounds, their expansion slightly increases stopping power against unarmed targets and reduces overpenetration.  Being caseless, these cannot be disassembled or reloaded.

An intermediate bullet, popularized during the first years of the Reclamation, these bullets are interchangeable between most modern assault rifles and machine guns.  These rounds being caseless cannot be disassembled or reloaded.

6.5mm Long Rifle ammunition with unjacketed bullets.  The 6.5mm LR round is extremely weak with very low stopping power, short range, and negligible recoil.  It is most extremely cheap to manufacture, and is only useful for rifle training, and hunting small animals.
